choices.text: Is a branch of the celiac trunk
Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen
Supplies the greater curvature of stomach

questions.text: All of the following statements about the splenic artery are true except that it:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen. Explanation for the Correct Answer: C. Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen: This statement is incorrect. While the splenic artery supplies blood to the spleen, its branches do not freely anastomose within the spleen. The branches of the splenic artery enter the spleen and form a series of branches that do not freely connect or form significant anastomoses. Instead, the blood supply to the spleen is divided into a series of end arteries that do not significantly anastomose with each other. Explanation for Incorrect Responses: A. Has a tortuous course: The splenic artery does indeed have a tortuous course. It is known for its winding or twisted path, which is a distinctive characteristic as it travels along the upper border of the pancreas and towards the spleen. B. Is a branch of the celiac trunk: The splenic artery is a direct branch of the celiac trunk, which is the main arterial supply to many abdominal structures, including the spleen, stomach, and liver. D. Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach: The splenic artery gives off the left gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach. This is a true statement, as the left gastroepiploic artery is a major contributor to the blood supply of the stomach's greater curvature.

choices.text: Gives short gastric arteries along the fundus

questions.text: Which of the following is true about splenic artery
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gives short gastric arteries along the fundus. Explanation for the Correct Answer: B. Gives short gastric arteries along the fundus: The splenic artery gives off the short gastric arteries that supply the fundus of the stomach. These arteries are key branches that arise from the splenic artery as it travels towards the spleen. These branches provide blood to the upper part of the stomach (fundus). Explanation for Incorrect Responses: A. Smaller than left gastric artery: The splenic artery is actually larger than the left gastric artery. The splenic artery supplies a larger area, including the spleen, pancreas, and parts of the stomach, while the left gastric artery mainly supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach. C. Curves around the fundus: This statement is incorrect. The splenic artery does not curve around the fundus. It runs along the upper border of the pancreas and gives off branches such as the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery, which supply the stomach. D. Arises from abdominal aorta: While the splenic artery does arise from the celiac trunk, not directly from the abdominal aorta. The celiac trunk is the direct branch of the abdominal aorta, but the splenic artery itself originates from the celiac trunk.

questions.text: All of the following are branches of splenic artery, EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right gastroepiploic artery. Explanation for the Correct Answer: C. Right gastroepiploic artery: The right gastroepiploic artery does not arise from the splenic artery. It is a branch of the gastroduodenal artery, which itself arises from the common hepatic artery. The right gastroepiploic artery supplies the greater curvature of the stomach and the omentum. Explanation for Incorrect Responses: A. Short gastric artery: The short gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery. These arteries supply the fundus of the stomach. They arise from the splenic artery as it travels towards the spleen. B. Hilar branches: The hilar branches are small arteries that supply the spleen itself. These branches are direct branches of the splenic artery, providing blood to the spleen as it enters through the hilum. D. Arteria pancreatica magna: The arteria pancreatica magna, or the great pancreatic artery, is a branch of the splenic artery. It supplies the pancreas and is part of the vascular supply of the pancreas.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is a direct branch of the gastroduodenal artery -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Right gastroepiploic artery. Explanation for the Correct Answer: D. Right gastroepiploic artery: The right gastroepiploic artery is a direct branch of the gastroduodenal artery. The gastroduodenal artery itself arises from the common hepatic artery and supplies the stomach, duodenum, and pancreas. The right gastroepiploic artery specifically supplies the right part of the greater curvature of the stomach and the omentum. Explanation for Incorrect Responses: A. Right gastric artery: The right gastric artery is not a branch of the gastroduodenal artery. It typically arises from the common hepatic artery or directly from the proper hepatic artery, and it supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach. B. Left gastric artery: The left gastric artery is a branch of the celiac trunk, not the gastroduodenal artery. It supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach and the esophagus. C. Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery: The inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery, not the gastroduodenal artery. It supplies the pancreas and duodenum, particularly the lower part of the duodenum.

choices.text: Is a branch of the coeliac trunk
Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen
Supplies the greater curvature of stomach

questions.text: All of the following statements about the splenic artery are true except that it -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen. Explanation for the Correct Answer: C. Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen: This statement is incorrect because while the splenic artery does give rise to branches that supply the spleen, these branches do not freely anastomose. Instead, the branches are end arteries that do not form significant anastomoses with other arterial sources within the spleen, meaning that if any branch is occluded, it could result in localized ischemia of the spleen. Explanation for Incorrect Responses: A. Has a tortuous course: This statement is true. The splenic artery is known for its tortuous (twisting and turning) course as it travels along the superior border of the pancreas toward the spleen. This tortuosity is a characteristic feature of the artery. B. Is a branch of the coeliac trunk: This statement is true. The splenic artery is indeed a branch of the coeliac trunk, which arises from the abdominal aorta. The splenic artery supplies the spleen, parts of the pancreas, and the greater curvature of the stomach. D. Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach: This statement is true. The splenic artery gives rise to the left gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach, as well as branches to the spleen and pancreas.

questions.text: All of the following are branches of splenic artery, Except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right Gastroepiploic Artery The right gastroepiploic artery is not a branch of the splenic artery. It is instead a branch of the gastroduodenal artery, which arises from the common hepatic artery. The right gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach, supplying the stomach and greater omentum, and anastomoses with the left gastroepiploic artery. Therefore, it does not originate from the splenic artery. Incorrect Responses: (A) Short Gastric Artery The short gastric arteries are branches of the splenic artery. They supply the fundus and upper part of the greater curvature of the stomach. These arteries arise as the splenic artery passes through the hilum of the spleen. (B) Hilar Branches Hilar branches are direct branches of the splenic artery that supply the spleen. They enter the spleen at the hilum, providing the arterial supply to this organ. (D) Arteria Pancreatica Magna The arteria pancreatica magna is a branch of the splenic artery that supplies the pancreas. This branch, along with other pancreatic branches from the splenic artery, is critical for the vascular supply of the body and tail of the pancreas.

questions.text: Main action of marked muscle on the TM joint in the below image is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The muscle marked here is lateral pterygoid. Actions of this muscle include Depression

questions.text: Downward enlargement of spleen is prevented by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Lienorenal ligament connects spleen with left kidney but it do not prevents downward enlargement of spleen. Option B-Phrenicocolic ligament aka sustentaculum lienis (sustentaculum= Support and Lienis= means spleen) so it is prevents downward enlargement of spleen. Option C-Head of pancreas doesn't lies in contact with spleen. Option D-Left renal artery also doesn't lies in contact with spleen.
